messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-08-31T19:09:18Z
## Message ID: 20190831-AL-004
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-08-31T18:50Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2019-08-30T12:17Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-08-31T18:50:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-08-31T15:34:18Z
## Message ID: 20190831-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2019-08-31T12:00Z to 2019-08-31T15:00Z. 

The storm is caused by HSS with ID 2019-08-30T12:17:00-HSS-001.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-08-31T12:00:00-GST-001.

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 21, 2019 - August 27, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-08-29T00:50:18Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-08-21T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-08-27T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190829-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=3 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2019-08-27T00:00Z-06:00Z and 2019-08-27T09:00Z-12:00Z.  This minor elevation in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2019-08-27.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2019-08-27.  

STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of the same coronal hole high speed stream described above around 2019-08-25.  The solar wind speed reached similar values of ~600 km/s on 2019-08-25. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-08-28T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-09-03T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are no active regions visible on the solar surface.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-09-02.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 14, 2019 - August 20, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-08-22T00:44:07Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-08-14T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-08-20T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190822-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream on 2019-08-20.  The solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2019-08-21.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed 

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-08-21T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-08-27T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are no active regions currently present on the solar disk.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to a possible arrival of a weak coronal hole high speed stream predicted around 2019-08-21.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 07, 2019 - August 13, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-08-15T01:55:38Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-08-07T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-08-13T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190815-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was above the threshold of 10^5 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period until 2019-08-11.  These elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt were associated to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2019-08-05 (see notifications 20190806-AL-001, 20190806-AL-002, 20190808-AL-001, and 20190810-AL-001).  After 2019-08-11, they went back to nominal levels and have remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the rest of the reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-08-14T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-08-20T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are no active regions visible on the solar disk.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a weak coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-08-16.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued  Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-08-10T14:01:31Z
## Message ID: 20190810-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with IDs 20190806-AL-002 and 20190808-AL-001. Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes continue in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-08-06T13:10Z and has continued to be above or near 70% - 80% of the threshold.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2019-08-05T01:15Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-08-06T13:10:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-08-08T13:30:07Z
## Message ID: 20190808-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notification with ID 20190806-AL-002. Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-08-06T13:10Z and has continued to be above or near the threshold.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by high speed stream starting at 2019-08-05T01:15Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-08-06T13:10:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for July 31, 2019 - August 06, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-08-07T20:45:13Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-07-31T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-08-06T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190807-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.   There were no major solar flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The largest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2019-08-05T06:00Z-18:00Z.  This minor geomagnetic storm was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2019-08-05.  The solar wind speed reached values of ~750 km/s on 2019-08-06.  

STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a weak coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-08-04.  Solar wind speed reached values of 450 km/s.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-08-06T13:10Z and are still currently elevated above the threshold.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES are associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20190806-AL-001 and 20190806-AL-002).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-08-07T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-08-13T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-08-11.  Currently, the energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt are still above the threshold of 10^5 pfu.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
